title: Future with 'Going to'
description: We use 'going to' to talk about plans or things we have already decided to do in the future. It is also used for predictions based on what we see.

subtopics.title: Affirmative Sentences
subtopics.description: Use 'am/is/are going to' + base verb to talk about future plans.

examples.sample: I am going to visit my friend.
She is going to study tonight.
We are going to play football.

subtopics.title: Negative Sentences
subtopics.description: Use 'am/is/are not going to' + base verb to say something will not happen.

examples.sample: I am not going to eat pizza.
He is not going to come.
They are not going to travel.

subtopics.title: Questions
subtopics.description: Put 'am/is/are' before the subject to ask about future plans.

examples.sample: Are you going to watch TV?
Is she going to call you?
Am I going to pass the test?

subtopics.title: Predictions
subtopics.description: Use 'going to' for predictions when you see something now.

examples.sample: Look at the clouds. It is going to rain.
Be careful! You are going to fall.
Our team is going to win.

exercises.question: Which is correct for a plan?
options: I am going to visit my friend.
exercises.correct: I am going to visit my friend.

exercises.question: How do you ask about a future plan?

exercises.instruction: Rewrite as a question: 'They are going to travel.'
Write a prediction: 'Look at the sky. It ___ (rain).'
